awd_titl_txt: Travel: Student Travel Grant for the Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop at PLDI 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
A Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop (PLMW) is being organized as part of the 43rd ACM SIGPLAN Conference on Programming Language Design and Implementation (PLDI), the premier forum in the field of programming languages and programming systems research, covering the areas of design, implementation, theory, applications, and performance. The conference will be held in San Diego, California. This award specifically supports students from underrepresented groups and gives priority to US citizens and permanent residents to attend the mentoring workshop in addition to the PLDI conference. The impact of the award relates to broadening participation in computing, providing opportunities for students to receive mentoring from leading researchers, and building the next generation of researchers and knowledgeable practitioners in programming languages and programming systems research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported travel grants to the Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop (PLMW), co-located with the conference on Programming Languages Design and Implementation (PLDI) 2022, held in San Diego, California, on June 13th and 14th, 2022.

This workshop is part of a long-running series of mentoring workshops that focus on bringing undergraduate and early-career graduate students to major conferences in programming languages and delivering a set of talks, panel discussions, and events to introduce them to programming languages research topics, provide mentoring (e.g., how to network, how to deliver talks, how to choose a research project), and foster networking (e.g., through mentoring breakfasts and dinners). These workshops especially target students from smaller schools that may not have access to suitable mentors in programming languages.

This grant supported the participation of US-based students at PLMW. The workshop was attended by 57 students, of which 39 students were supported by this grant. Of those 39 students, 13 were women, and 1 was from an underrepresented group.

Students supported by the grant had:

1. Registration at the host conference (PLDI 2022) waived

2. Hotel rooms booked and paid for by the workshop

3. Travel costs defrayed in the form of a fixed (partial) reimbursement of airfare.
